[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.1 Purpose: The Token-Ring LAN Management System (TRMS) defines requirements for managing token-ring LAN communication, node control, and packet transmission.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.2 Scope: TRMS supports node communication, transmission, and real-time monitoring.

[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.1 System Interfaces: TRMS integrates with network diagnostics, monitoring tools, and printing services.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.2 User Interfaces: TRMS allows administrators to configure nodes and monitor traffic.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.3 Hardware Interfaces: TRMS supports network adapters, switches, and token-based access devices.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.4 Software Interfaces: TRMS uses TCP/IP, SNMP, and encryption protocols.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.5 Communications Interfa: TRMS secures data via authentication mechanisms.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.6 Memory Constraints: TRMS is optimized for low-latency packet processing.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.7 Operations: TRMS manages token circulation, node communication, and message routing between workstations, servers, and printers.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.8 Site Adaptation Requir: TRMS is configurable for small and large networks.
[SUBSEC] 1.3 Product Perspective.[SUBSUBSEC] 1.3.9 Interfaces with Servic: TRMS connects with network logging, alert, and monitoring systems.

[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.4 Product Functions: TRMS handles packet transmission, network routing, and node communication.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.5 User Characteristics: TRMS is designed for network administrators and IT engineers.
[SEC] 1. Introduction.[SUBSEC] 1.7 Assumptions and Dependencie: TRMS relies on active token circulation and node stability.
[SUBSEC] 1.8 Definitions: Node: Workstation, server, or networked device.

[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-001: The system shall manage token passing for node communication (REQ-DB-85).
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-002: The system shall track packet traffic and node activity logs (REQ-PERF-002).
[SUBSEC] 2.1 External Interfaces.REQ-INTF-003: The system shall support integration with security monitoring tools (REQ-DB-96).

[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-001: The system shall ensure token-based access control for network transmission (REQ-DB-43).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-002: The system shall allow administrators to configure network settings and monitor traffic (REQ-PERF-002).
[SUBSEC] 2.2 Functions.REQ-FUNC-003: The system shall log packet transmission history and detect anomalies (REQ-PERF-003).

[SUBSEC] 2.3 Usability Requirements.REQ-USAB-001: The system shall provide a real-time network status dashboard.

[SUBSEC] 2.4 Performance Requirements.REQ-PERF-001: The system shall process packets with minimal delay.

[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-001: The system shall store token-passing history and node status.
[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-002: The system shall track packet logs and error reports.
[SUBSEC] 2.5 Logical Database Requiremen.REQ-DB-003: The system shall maintain network topology and security logs.

[SUBSEC] 2.6 Design Constraints.REQ-DSGN-001: The system shall ensure unique identification for all network nodes.

[SUBSEC] 2.7 Standards Compliance.REQ-COMP-001: The system shall comply with IEEE 802.5 networking standards.

[SUBSEC] 2.8 Software System Attributes.REQ-ATTR-001: The system shall maintain network logs for compliance.

[SEC] 3. Verification: Tests token passing, node configuration, and network logging.
[SEC] 4. Supporting Information: User manuals, API documentation, and troubleshooting guides.
[SEC] 5. References: IEEE 802.5 standards, network security policies, and monitoring protocols.
